stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and fine-tunes several Wild-West NPCs (Dry Bones "tumbleweed" enemy, saloon piano Shy Guy, and a shoot-out rival "Cow Boshi") for the retro section of Return to Yoshi’s Island (Course 14). He also drafts cowboy dialogue, duel mechanics, sound hooks and camera work while discussing tooling, hardware and his design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: Dry Bones desert variant completed: line-of-sight chase, acceleration/deceleration tuning, animation speed scaling, crumble/rebuild cycle, custom footstep SFX and pushable collision.
development_findings.quote: I usually scale animations with the walking speed; it’s the easiest thing to make good-looking.

development_findings.summary: Cow Boshi duel mini-game scripted: randomised countdown, B-button quick-draw, adaptive timing that lengthens after each player loss to accommodate human reaction times.
development_findings.quote: Every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier, just to make sure everyone can beat it.

development_findings.summary: Camera framing for the shoot-out iterated; Kaze freezes world, positions zoom and angle until the composition feels like classic Western standoffs.
development_findings.quote: It’s high noon – I want the camera like this though… something like this.

development_findings.summary: New piano-playing Shy Guy NPC prepared; Kaze halves texture size and fixes UVs to save memory before sending the rig back to Zeina for animation.
Collaborative secret sub-level with Aza in the same course; Kaze is handling gameplay while Aza handles a second area, allowing them to "cash in twice" on popularity.
development_findings.quote: I was planning a level anyway, so we can just double cash in, you know what I mean?

development_findings.summary: Sound system placeholders: environmental barrels, tumbleweed roll, and dry-bones shuffle added with low-priority, quick-falloff settings; full SFX pass deferred to end of development.
Framework decision: sticks with Project64 1.6 despite virus warnings because it boots fastest and works with his toolchain; PowerLauncher doesn’t run on his PC.
development_findings.quote: It doesn’t work on my PC, so what do you want me to do – buy a new PC just to use an emulator?

development_findings.summary: Ongoing performance investigation: new F3DEX microcode branch 'fpdx' still "too slow"; will debug with Sauron later.
VS Code intellisense suddenly fixed itself, giving autofill suggestions that speed coding.
development_findings.quote: Oh my god, suddenly I’m seeing all these recommendations from VS Code – you guys seeing that?

context_findings.summary: Kaze frames each project as a learning experiment, not merely entertainment.
context_findings.quote: I make things because I want to see them… I’m going to learn from this and become even better.

context_findings.summary: He differentiates intrinsic vs extrinsic motivation in games, praising Tears of the Kingdom and GTA for intrinsic fun while criticising recent Pokémon.
context_findings.quote: Playing Pokémon kind of feels like a job… whereas if you build a machine in Tears of the Kingdom it’s pure intrinsic motivation.

context_findings.summary: Expresses disdain for parasocial chatter (e.g., asking what he ate) and ‘farming’ viewers.
context_findings.quote: Talking what you ate feels so incredibly narcissistic to me – who gives a shit?

context_findings.summary: Shows frustration with repetitive tool advice (PowerLauncher) and ‘stupid questions’, revealing occasional tension with chat.
Mentions fitness routine (push/pull/legs every four days) and large water jug, hinting at work-life balance discipline.
Philosophical musing on simulation theory and meaning of work; ties back to intrinsic motivation outlook.
context_findings.quote: All the work you will ever do is for nothing unless you have an intrinsic motivation to do it.

biobak.summary: Gives marketing-style feedback and reminds Kaze of a hotkey for unpacking resources; acts as technical and morale support.

zeina.summary: Animated Dry Bones model and designed piano-playing Shy Guy; receives models back for further animation passes.
zeina.quote: Zayna animated this guy here – the Dry Bones guy will be so happy.

zeina.summary: Participates in chat, lighthearted spousal banter (credit-card joke for hardware purchase).

key_stories.title: Tumbleweed Dry Bones
key_stories.summary: Kaze transforms a standard Dry Bones into a desert enemy that behaves like a zombie tumbleweed.
key_stories.challenge: Initial animations looked slow and the run cycle felt ‘too aggressive’.
key_stories.process: Scaled animation speed to velocity, added chase distance checks, tuned acceleration and integrated footstep and crumble sounds.
key_stories.outcome: NPC now feels lively and is marked ‘done’; SFX polish postponed to final audio pass.
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, most of the time when an animation looks off it’s because it’s in slow motion somehow.

key_stories.title: Cow Boshi Quick-Draw Duel
key_stories.summary: Design and first pass implementation of a Western shoot-out mini-game with an edgy Yoshi rival.
key_stories.challenge: Needed engaging mechanic accessible to players with varying reaction times.
key_stories.process: Wrote cowboy dialogue trees, scripted countdown with random delay, added adaptive reaction-window scaling, and positioned cinematic camera.
key_stories.outcome: Core logic complete; awaiting Boshi animations and final polish.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you lose the game gets a little bit easier so everyone can beat it.

key_stories.title: Secret Collaboration Level
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Aza each build a sub-area for Course 14, letting them cross-promote while sharing workload.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain surprise and avoid spoilers on stream.
key_stories.process: Kaze codes gameplay while hiding visuals; privately DMs Biobak for feedback.
key_stories.outcome: Level ‘looking really good’; reveals postponed for official debut.
key_stories.key_quote: I was not supposed to show it yet… we can just double cash in.
